SEARCH
Package org.uma.evolver.algorithm.base.nsgaii.parameterspace

Class NSGAIICommonParameterSpace<S extends org.uma.jmetal.solution.Solution<?>>

java.lang.Object
org.uma.evolver.parameter.ParameterSpace
org.uma.evolver.algorithm.base.nsgaii.parameterspace.NSGAIICommonParameterSpace<S>
Type Parameters:
S - the solution type handled by the algorithm
Direct Known Subclasses:
NSGAIIBinaryParameterSpace, NSGAIIDoubleParameterSpace, NSGAIIPermutationParameterSpace
public abstract class NSGAIICommonParameterSpace<S extends org.uma.jmetal.solution.Solution<?>> extends ParameterSpace
Abstract parameter space for NSGA-II algorithm variants.

This class defines the common configurable parameters, their relationships, and top-level parameters for any NSGA-II implementation (e.g., real-coded, permutation-based). Subclasses should extend this class and add any additional parameters or relationships specific to their encoding.

Typical parameters include:

  • Algorithm result type (population or external archive)
  • Population size (with or without archive)
  • Initial solutions creation strategy
  • Variation (crossover and mutation)
  • Selection operator and its configuration

Parameter relationships and dependencies are also defined, ensuring that the configuration is consistent and valid.

Subclasses should override setParameterSpace(), setParameterRelationships(), and setTopLevelParameters() as needed.

Example of extension: 


 public class NSGAIIDoubleParameterSpace extends NSGAIICommonParameterSpace<DoubleSolution> {
   // Add double-specific parameters and relationships here
 }

  • Constructor Details

    • NSGAIICommonParameterSpace

      public NSGAIICommonParameterSpace()

  • Method Details

    • setParameterSpace

      protected void setParameterSpace()
      Defines and adds all common parameters to the parameter space for NSGA-II variants.

      This includes parameters such as algorithm result type, population size with archive, external archive type, offspring population size, variation, selection strategy, and tournament size. Subclasses should call super and then add their own specific parameters.

    • setParameterRelationships

      protected void setParameterRelationships()
      Establishes relationships and dependencies between parameters in the parameter space.

      For example, if the algorithm result is set to use an external archive, then the population size with archive and the external archive type become relevant sub-parameters. Similarly, the variation and selection parameters may have their own specific sub-parameters.

    • setTopLevelParameters

      protected void setTopLevelParameters()
      Identifies and adds the top-level parameters to the list.

      Top-level parameters are the main entry points for user configuration and are typically exposed in user interfaces or command-line tools.
